habitat: Most common species of earthball in woods, heathland and in short grass from autumn to winter. Widely distributed across Europe and Asia. Attached to soil by mycelial cords
shortDescription: Superficially similar to edible puffball but earthball breaks up to release spores rather than having single opening on top. Has much firmer flesh and dark interior much earlier in development than puffballs. No stem but attached to soil by mycelial cords
benefitsOrToxicity: Poisonous. Ingestion can cause gastrointestinal issues. <!-- Thông tin độc tính cụ thể không được nêu rõ trong nguồn, cần tìm thêm -->

identification.cap: 4–12cm across and 3–6cm tall; tough skin is dirty-yellow to ochre-brown and covered in coarse, warty scales in irregular shapes; as fungus matures, can turn ochre-brown or green
identification.gills: No gills - this is a puffball-type mushroom
identification.stem: Doesn't have a stem but does have a few root-like mycelial threads which are attached to the soil
identification.flesh: Inside young earthball is whitish, sometimes with pink-purple tinge; as it ages, flesh becomes purple-brown to black with what looks like small white 'veins' running through it
identification.microscopicFeatures: Individual spores are spherical and spiked. Spore mass is grayish, becoming purply-black, marbled at first by white veins and powdery when mature. When mature, outer skin ruptures, creating large irregular opening that releases spores dispersed by wind and rain

note: First described by Christian Hendrik Persoon in 1801. Scleroderma fungi are close relatives of boletes, particularly genus Gyroporus. The generic name Scleroderma comes from Greek for 'hard skin'. The specific epithet citrinum refers to the 'lemon-yellow' color. Other common names include Kartoffelbovist (German), Scléroderme vulgaire, and Scléroderme orangé (French).
